metadata.title: Medial Tibial Stress Syndrome
anatomical location body part affected: Posteromedial distal two-thirds  of the tibia
description: Medial tibial stress syndrome (MTSS) is an exercise-induced  lower leg pain usually experienced while running or during other weight-bearing  activities

ICD-10 codes.S86.819: A strain of specified muscle and tendon at lower leg level
ICD-10 codes.S86.919: A strain of unspecified muscles or tendons at lower leg level (ICD codes are provided for readers’ reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Signs and symptoms associated with MTSS can include(5) –exercise-induced  pain along the distal two-thirds  of the medial tibial border –pain provocation during or after physical activity and decreases with rest –absence of cramping –burning pain over the posterior compartment and/or numbness or tingling in the foot Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Symptoms may overlap with those of other medical conditions, such as tibial stress fractures or chronic exertional compartment syndrome.(5) Thus, these conditions should be carefully ruled out –Please see Clinical Review…Compartment Syndrome, Chronic; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T708750 for more information about this condition

pathogenesis: The pathogenesis of MTSS is unclear. However, the following theories have beenproposed:–Traction theory – Repeated traction and pulling of the muscles connected to the tibialperiosteum. May involve the soleus, tibialis posterior, and flexor digitorum longus. Thedeep fascia of the leg (crural fascia) may also be involved–Bone stress-failure  theory – The inability of the tibia to adequately respond torepetitive forces; possibly due to biomechanical or muscular weakness
risk factors: Intrinsic–Low tibial bone mineral density–High BMI(5,15)–Female sex(5,11)–Previous running injury(11)–History of MTSS(15)–Positive navicular drop (ND) test; greater navicular drop(11)–Decreased flexibility of the transverse arch and medial longitudinal arch–Increased hip internal and external rotation ROM(11)–Tightness of the iliotibial band(9)–Weakness of the hip abductors(9)–Increased pressure on medial aspect of foot during initial foot contact and heel off(9)–Greater contralateral pelvic drop(9)–Increased peak amount and duration of rearfoot eversion during stance phase(9)–High soleus muscle activity during stance phase of running(15)

overall contraindications precautions: MTSS may develop into a stress fracture if not cared for properly(5)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Symptoms may overlap with those of other medical conditions, such as tibial stress fractures or chronic exertional compartment syndrome.(5) Thus, these conditions should be carefully ruled out –Please see Clinical Review…Compartment Syndrome, Chronic; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T708750 for more information about this condition

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -When did symptoms first develop, and was there any trauma? -Has exertional tibial pain gradually worsened, or did pain start suddenly? -Has there been an abrupt increase in training intensity, duration, or frequency? -Has the onset of symptoms occurred with new activities, such as hill training? -Ask about training surfaces and footwear

course of treatment.medical management: Ask about patient’s past and current medical management. How has the lower leg responded to treatments?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed, if any; are they being taken? Are they effective?
diagnostic tests completed: An MRI might also be utilized to evaluate for MTSS. Because no radiation is involved, an MRI might be the best diagnostic imaging option(5)
CT scan  detects stress-induced  bone remodeling
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -Typically the patient will complain of an increase in symptoms during running, jumping, or periods of high activity level -In the early stage, pain occurs at beginning of a run and then resolves, only to recur after the run. In later stages, the pain might persist following activity -Document whether pain occurs with walking -Does changing footwear affect pain?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Pain in areas other than the inner shaft of the middle and distal thirds of tibia (either unilateral or bilateral) may be indicative of another diagnosis
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Symptoms may range from diffuse/dull pain to sharp, severe pain
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables (e.g., footwear used, terrain/surface)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Sleep disturbance -Document number of wakings/night -Is there night pain?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., paresthesia, muscle weakness, pallor, edema, diminished pulse) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Any previous history of MTSS or stress fractures? Any previous skeletal problems or lower extremity injury?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she might be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the pain associated with certain recreational activities, sports, or occupations? Inquire about footwear used. Does the patient smoke?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document the use of any assistive or adaptive devices (e.g., crutches, cane, walking boot, ankle brace)
social and occupational history.living environment: Inquire about stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, and caregivers. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –Measure height and weight and calculate BMI. High BMI is a risk factor for MTSS
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess single-leg  balance and compare bilaterally
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Assess pelvic, hip, knee, and ankle motion during gait and running -Abnormalities may include irregular phasic muscle activity, overpronation of the midfoot, external rotation and eversion of the subtalar joint –Assess footwear  –Based on a cross-sectional  study in Japan, athletes with MTSS demonstrate rearfoot eversion during the stance phase of gait and high foot pressure under the medial metatarsal region with a more medial center of pressure. The authors concluded that rearfoot malignment can be detected during gait, even if alignment appears normal in stance(17) –Based on a study in Japan, individuals with MTSS exhibit kinematic abnormalities during walking and running and have significantly greater(14) -hindfoot eversion and abduction during walking and running -forefoot eversion and abduction during walking -forefoot abduction during running Joint integrity and mobility –Talocrural joint mobility is usually normal despite reduced flexibility of plantarflexors in many cases –Assess the subtalar joint, tibiotalar joint, and intrinsic joints of the foot(3) –If patient overpronates, assess for subtalar joint accessory hypermobility
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –In unilateral MTSS, compare strength of ankle musculature (i.e., invertors, evertors, plantarflexors, and dorsiflexors) in the affected leg to uninvolved leg –Assess hip abduction and external rotation strength, as strengthening these muscle groups has been shown to change lower extremity loading during running (e.g., rearfoot eversion, hip internal rotation), which might reduce the risk of injury(9)
observation inspection palpation includi: Patients have tenderness to palpation over the posteromedial edge of tibia and surrounding musculature (medial gutter). If localized bony tenderness is discovered, a stress fracture, not MTSS, should be suspected(5) -Presence of reproducible pain along the posteromedial tibial border > 5 cm(5)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Visually assess for pes planus/subtalar joint position with the patient standing. Also look for increased femoral or tibial internal rotation –Assess subtalar neutral in non-weight-bearing  (including rearfoot, forefoot, and the first ray)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Check for normal ROM at the knee and ankle, calf muscle tightness/shortening
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: The assessment should yield normal results for sensation and proprioception
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisthe patient is asked to stand on one leg and lift heel repeatedly. Pain might be elicited if MTSS is present(6) –Provocation of pain with passive ankle dorsiflexion and resisted ankle plantarflexionan objective measure of foot pronation. With the patient in a sitting position, the most prominent point of the navicular tubercle is marked. The patient is then asked to stand on one leg (with one hand on the wall or back of a chair for support) while the examiner places the foot in subtalar neutral. The distance from the floor to the marked navicular tubercle is measured. The patient is then asked to relax the foot and the examiner repeats the measure. A navicular drop greater than 10 mm in the relaxed versus the subtalar neutral position is considered positive(10)

contraindications precautions: During pregnancy, over the abdomen and low back
Over active bone growth at the epiphysis
Over a known or suspected area for cancer
Over the infected tissue in a tuberculosis infection
Over an area of active bleeding  can be used in area of hematoma
Over skin with impaired circulation  recommend use pulsed

The following are considered contraindications but have no evidence to support -Myositis ossificans -Deep vein thrombosis or thrombophlebitis -Acute injury -Recently irradiated tissue -Impaired sensation due to nerve damage -Skin disease -Implanted cardiac pacemaker or other implanted electronics -Reproductive organs -Eyes -Anterior neck
Metal implants, head, and heart often listed but consensus is there should not be contraindications
Over spinal cord and superficial or regenerating nerves (poor evidence)
Over low back and abdomen during pregnancy
Over known or suspected area of malignancy

The following are considered contraindications but have no evidence to support -Myositis ossificans -Deep vein thrombosis or thrombophlebitis -Recently irradiated tissue -Implanted cardiac pacemaker or other implanted electronics -Reproductive organs -Eyes -Anterior neck
Over epiphysis with active bone growth
Over area of impaired sensation due to nerve damage
With patients with impaired cognition or communication
In the presence of skin disease
Over plastic and cemented implants -Over spinal cord and superficial or regenerating nerves (poor evidence)
Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
Over an area of poor sensation
In the very young or very old
Over areas with a lack of intact thermal sensation
Over areas of vascular insufficiency or vascular disease
Over areas of recent hemorrhage or potential hemorrhage
Over infected areas where infection may spread
Over areas where liniments or heat rubs have recently been applied
In any situation deemed unreliable by the practitioner
Postoperative surgical incision with dehiscence (i.e., bleeding surgical wound), sutures, or staples
Skin ulcers caused by venous insufficiency, edema, or lymphedema
Skin conditions such as atopic eczema, ichthyosis, and senile pruritus (i.e., itching)
Tissue flaps or recent skin grafts
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment in their assessment and treatment decisions

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide and does not replace orders from a physician or the specific protocols of the treatment clinic

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The assessment provides a basis for addressing extrinsic and intrinsic risk factors and for the introduction of safe exercises to resolve pain-restricted  activity
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Periostitis Tibial (or fibular) stress fracture(5) Pes anserine bursitis Venous stasis Osteosarcoma
prognosis: Prognosis is good with relative rest, activity modification, and conservative care. In the absence of other leg pathology, most patients return to their regular activities and resume sports participation after symptoms resolve and optimal pain-free function is restored
Full recovery is expected with activity modifications and proper rest(5)
Untreated MTSS can eventually cause changes to the lower limb joint angles, leading to reduction in low back and hamstring flexibility(7)
Approximate recovery time for MTSS is 16 to 18 weeks(16)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Orthopedic physician as indicated Podiatrist Orthotist Acupuncturist
other considerations: Extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT) –In a study conducted in Colombia, researchers concluded that one application of ESWT combined with exercise training accelerated the clinical and functional outcomes of military cadets who were experiencing MTSS(4)

Arch support orthoses can be an effective tool to normalize foot pressure distributions for persons with MTSS by correcting abnormalities of foot pressure during the loading response phase and lateral shift during the propulsion phase(8)
treatment summary: Conservative management of MTSS –Activity modification, cryotherapy for pain management, stretching and strengthening exercises, and lessening of modifiable risk factors to promote healing and to prevent recurrence of injury –The addition of arch support foot orthoses to therapeutic intervention (i.e., ice massage, ankle muscle exercises, and ESWT) is associated with earlier improvement in pain and MTSS severity, improved physical function, and perceived therapeutic effects(12)

Kinesiology taping –Based on a 2021 systematic review of four studies with a total of 141 participants, the efficacy of kinesiology taping is unclear and evidence supporting its effectiveness in individuals with MTSS is limited(13) –Researchers in the United States found that application of lower-leg kinesiology tape in patients with current or previous history of MTSS might reduce MTSS by changing the loading rate onto the medial foot(2) -In a study comparing time-to-peak  force (TTPF), measured while walking across a plantar pressure mat, 20 healthy subjects and 20 subjects with history of MTSS were tested before tape application, immediately after tape, and after 24 hours of continuous tape wear -Before tape application, participants with MTSS presented with lower medial midfoot TTPF. Medial midfoot TTPF significantly increased following tape application, becoming closer to that of the healthy subjects -The authors suggest that kinesiology taping might be used as a preventive strategy for patients susceptible to MTSS

. Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Pain and tenderness along the posteromedial border of the tibiaReduce pain and tendernessPhysical agents and mechanical modalities _ Cryotherapy for pain and edema; heat, whirlpool, and contrast baths to relieve stiffness _ _ Activity modification _ Restrict high-impact activities such as running and jumping. Try low-impact cross- training (bicycling, elliptical trainer, water running, swimming) _ _ Prescription, application of devices and equipment _ Crutches or an assistive device might be utilized temporarily if the condition is severeN/A Educate patient on cryotherapy use and appropriate activities in which to participate outside of therapy Subtalar overpronation Improve subtalar stabilityPrescription, application of devices and equipment _ Shock-absorbing insoles or high- cushioning athletic footwear and foam heel pads for a rigid foot, supportive orthotic insoles for reducing overpronation in the hypermobile, overpronating foot(8) _ Kinesiology tape might be effective for reducing rate of medial forefoot loading(2)N/A Educate patient on orthotic use and wearing schedule  Reduced ankle and/ or 1st MTP joint dorsiflexion ROMIncrease to full or near- full ROMManual therapy _ Soft-tissue mobilization for palpable adhesions, passive ROM, stretching of shortened muscles. Joint mobilization of restricted joints to increase ROM _ _ Therapeutic exercises _ There is no strong research evidence to support the use of stretching and/or strengthening programs in MTSS. However, soleus stretching in the neutral subtalar joint position is recommended if ankle ROM is reduced in dorsiflexionProgress each unique patient as appropriate and indicatedImplement a home exercise program as appropriate and indicated Reduced strength in foot, ankle, knee, and/ or hipIncrease strength for sport, work, ADLsTherapeutic exercises _ In patients with weak hip and lower extremity musculature, might begin with open-chain exercises (e.g., clams and side-lying,straight- leg raises)(9)Progress to closed-chain leg muscle concentric strengthening (e.g., heel raises) to eccentric strengthening (e.g., heel step-downs), as appropriate and indicatedImplement a home exercise program as appropriate and indicated  Reduced ability to participate in sportsReturn to sport with a normalized gait pattern and/or running pattern; prevention of reinjuryGait training _ Improve gait mechanics to restore adequate step length. Eliminate gait deficits found due to weakness or restrictions in ROM _ _ Therapeutic exercise _ Balance, proprioception, and agility training _ _

maintenance or prevention: Shock-absorbing  insoles might help prevent shin splints in young male athletes by stabilizing the subtalar joint and decreasing overpronation(8)
Recommend continued stretching of the gastrocsoleus complex
Strengthen the lower extremity musculature as well as hip abductors and hip external rotators(9)

Based on a systematic review, novice and recreational runners should(16) undergo biomechanical analysis of running movements to identify and address risk factors for MTSS  use a proper kinematic running technique and incorporate strength and neuromuscular control exercises follow a gradual running program, includingincorporating proper recovery times, thus allowing for improved pain management and prevention of injury recurrence
